ComUnus is hashtag#hiring for Dotnet Developer!! 😊No Of Position : 5Exp. Req : 5+ YrsWork Location : Mumbai (Thane)Max NP : Immediate Joiners are preferredMust Have Skills : Micro ServicesPreferred Candidate : MumbaiKindly Note : Immediate Joiners are preferred !!Interested Candidates Share there CV on : vidhi.bhatti@comunus.in | 8591723284Key Responsibilities: 1. Design and Development: Develop high-quality web applications using ASP.NET, C#, and related technologies. 2. Architecture: Collaborate with internal teams to design software architecture and ensure scalability and performance. 3. Coding: Write clean, scalable, and maintainable code. 4. Testing and Deployment: Test and deploy applications and systems, ensuring they meet performance and security standards. 5. Maintenance: Maintain and update existing applications, troubleshoot issues, and provide technical support. 6. Code Reviews: Conduct code reviews to ensure code quality and adherence to best practices. Documentation: Develop and maintain documentation throughout the software development lifecycle (SDLC). 7. Innovation: Stay updated with the latest industry trends and technologies, and suggest improvements and new features. Qualifications: 1. Education: Bachelor’s or Master’s degree in Computer Science, Information Technology, or a related field. 2. Experience: 5+ years of experience in ASP.NET development. 3. Technical Skills: Proficiency in ASP.NET, C#, MVC, and Web API. 4. Strong understanding of front-end technologies such as HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and frameworks like Angular or React. 5. Experience with database design and development using SQL Server. 6. Knowledge of cloud platforms like Azure or AWS. Familiarity with version control systems like Git. 7. Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring

Let me explain clearly:How an API works — in C# context An API (Application Programming Interface) is just a way for one program (or system) to talk to another in a standard way, usually over HTTP/HTTPS if it’s a web API.In C#, you often build Web APIs using ASP.NET Core Web API.Basic Idea:A client (like Postman, a browser, or a mobile app) sends an HTTP request (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) to your API.Your API receives the request, processes it (maybe talks to a database or performs logic), and sends back an HTTP response, usually in JSON format.📌 Steps in C#:Create a Web API ProjectIn Visual Studio:File → New → Project → ASP.NET Core Web APIDefine a ControllerA controller is a C# class that defines the endpoints of your API.What happens when you run it:You run the API (dotnet run or press F5 in Visual Studio).The API listens on a URL like: https://localhost:5001You can send HTTP requests to endpoints like:GET /api/productsGET /api/products/1POST /api/productsTools to Test:Use Postman or browser for GET requests.For POST/PUT you can send JSON body via Postman.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#SqlServer hashtag#DotNet hashtag#MicroSoft hashtag#AdoDotNet hashtag#Linkedin hashtag#Fresher hashtag#BengaluruTech hashtag#Bengaluru hashtag#AspDotNetCore hashtag#WebApi hashtag#SwaggerUi hashtag#BackEndDeveloper hashtag#Microsoft hashtag#MicrosoftDeveloper hashtag#OpenToNetWork hashtag#SoftWare hashtag#Hiring
